13.73.text:
The beauty of London is that it's constantly
changing, if you are tired of London you are

18.99.text:
tired of life, it offers everything
which life affords.

29.75.text:
London was probably the first marketplace
that congregated the jewels companies together,

34.74.text:
congregated the banks together in one place,
if you want to buy diamonds there is one area

39.75.text:
in London that you go to. I think the major
benefit of Silicon Roundabout is that all

45.10.text:
the skills are there, the developers the coders,
the founders the incubators are in one place.

51.33.text:
You can move around, the DNA gets mixed up
nicely, you can hang out with your peers.

61.53.text:
Having seen Silicon Valley and being actually
from Germany and having lived in Berlin before,

66.45.text:
London is definitely one of the best places
in the world because unlike Silicon Valley

71.13.text:
it is actually a metropolitan area which is
very condense there is a lot of things going

76.20.text:
on in a very small space, so I can just walk
to Google Campus from here and meet a lot

81.50.text:
of great other startups. In Silicon Valley
you always have to have a car, you have to

85.09.text:
drive to the next place or you have to go
to San Francisco, which also is a great city

89.39.text:
to start a company, but London is special
in that, it's one of the biggest cities in

94.28.text:
the world, is one of the centers of the world.
There is a huge ecosystem that is a lot bigger

99.96.text:
than the one in Berlin for example, there
are so many advisors, people with a lot of

104.61.text:
knowledge, big companies that you can actually
work with so that's I guess one of the big

109.45.text:
differences. There is a lot of companies that
you can sign up as a customer because they

113.58.text:
are big themselves and they have cash to spend
on a good solution.

125.20.text:
I mean I feel Google Campus is a real focus
for a lot of the amazing energy that London

129.50.text:
already had but has now been focused particularly
around tech city in the area where we are

135.25.text:
now. It's a pretty amazing building in the
sense that you get a really high volume of

141.44.text:
people from all different backgrounds, 
abilities, ages, interests.

150.90.text:
You are in a special place with Campus here,
this is pretty much ground zero for the London

155.64.text:
Startup Scene and everyone kind of knows the
Roundabout and this building here so it's

161.38.text:
a pretty special place to be in because different
partners in different levels, different floors,

168.21.text:
it's a real open source building so you get
such a hub of activity here so it's pretty

173.96.text:
awesome, and again there is just a ton of
companies all around here.

186.60.text:
It's quite expensive to have a studio here,
London is not a kind of cheap place to be

190.31.text:
in but it constantly keeps you on your toes,
the very fact of having this sort of expensive

194.97.text:
rent forces you to push harder and work harder
just to stay in flow and I think it have a

200.09.text:
really positive impact on creativity. I see
a lot of cities which are maybe more comfortable

204.65.text:
and easier and cheaper to stay in, feel I don't
know if it's true, slightly more kinda relaxed

210.89.text:
and I think for this sort of work is quite
nice to be on your toes and have to work hard

223.57.text:
Everywhere I traveled in on the planet has
their own Silicon Roundabout, Silicon Valley,

227.81.text:
some sort of like you know Silicon rip-off
somewhere there and the big problem is always

233.11.text:
access to capital because you can have incredibly
motivated entrepreneurs willing to bootstrap,

239.55.text:
pivoting every 17 or 18 seconds because they
are dreadfully fashionable and being as lean

244.30.text:
as the possibly can and having a minimum viable
product whatever this trendy trendy thing

249.08.text:
is. But if they haven't got access to capital
the whole thing is doomed and I think it's

255.00.text:
somehow about integrating that. The UK is
incredibly lucky that they have got amazing

260.90.text:
tax incentives for angels EIS, SEIS, which
effectively mean you invest a hundred into

267.36.text:
a company and you have paid a hundred in tax,
you get 50 of it back immediately. Then should

274.47.text:
something dreadful happen you can rates the
rest of it all flat your top level of tax,

278.73.text: so you know, you are in for a very very little.

289.20.text:
I've been here for 8 years and I think the
attitude hasn't changed, British government

295.90.text:
and industries here really understand the
role of innovation in the economy. What has

302.25.text:
changed of course is that we have been through
a massive crisis and the budgets are smaller

307.76.text:
but I think honestly I wouldn't go anywhere
else, at least in Europe.

322.57.text:
The entrepreneurship scene in London but also
the UK has become incredibly vibrant so I

328.01.text:
was part of a campaign that launched called
Startup Britain three years ago and over that

332.78.text:
time the UK has now seen record numbers of
people starting a business so this year there

337.62.text:
will be half a million people start a business
in the UK which is incredible and what we

341.85.text:
have seen is the flourishing amount of support
available for startup businesses. So wherever

346.64.text:
you turn you get either support from peer
or you get support from proven entrepreneurs

350.52.text:
who have done that business and are now giving
back. So it's a great time to be starting

354.68.text:
a business in Britain and I think there will
be a big focus next year on encouraging all
